context: Everton were founder members of the Premier League in <a0_0><b7_0>1992<b7_0/><a0_0/>, but struggled to find the right manager. <b5_0>Howard Kendall<b5_0/> had returned in <a1_0><b6_0>1990<b6_0/><a1_0/> but could not repeat his previous success, while his successor, <a2_0>Mike Walker<a2_0/>, was statistically the least successful Everton manager to date. When former Everton player Joe Royle took over in <a3_0>1994<a3_0/> the club's form started to improve; his first game in charge was a <a4_0><b8_0>2–0<b8_0/><a4_0/> victory over derby rivals Liverpool. Royle dragged Everton clear of relegation, leading the club to the FA Cup for the fifth time in its history, defeating Manchester United <b9_0>1–0<b9_0/> in the final.
